title: Perforated Diverticulitis with Pericolic Abscess
setup_script: A 58-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. CT scan shows sigmoid diverticulitis with a 4 cm pericolic abscess (Hinchey II) and no free air.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Assess severity of abdominal pain, fever, and previous episodes of diverticulitis; review comorbidities.
Perform physical exam; note localized tenderness without diffuse peritonitis.
Order labs (CBC, CMP, lactate) and CT to classify disease; identify pericolic abscess.
Discuss management options: antibiotics alone, percutaneous drainage, or urgent surgery depending on size and response.
Initiate IV antibiotics and fluids; consult interventional radiology for percutaneous abscess drainage.
Perform percutaneous drainage under CT guidance; send fluid for culture and sensitivity.
Monitor patient for improvement; repeat imaging to assess resolution; continue antibiotics for 7-10 days.
Plan elective sigmoid resection after inflammation subsides due to complicated diverticulitis.
Discuss options for laparoscopy versus open surgery and primary anastomosis versus Hartmann's procedure.
At elective surgery, perform sigmoidectomy with primary colorectal anastomosis and protective diverting loop ileostomy if risk factors present.
Postoperative care: manage stoma, monitor for anastomotic leak, and gradually advance diet.
Provide education on diverticular disease prevention (high-fiber diet), follow-up colonoscopy, and stoma reversal timing.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate classification of diverticulitis severity using Hinchey system.
Decision for percutaneous drainage versus immediate surgery based on abscess size and patient stability.
Timing of elective sigmoidectomy and choice of anastomosis with or without diversion.
Monitoring for complications post drainage and surgery.
Patient education about lifestyle modifications and surveillance colonoscopy.
